The sets V_0,...,V_K give a polyhedral decomposition of R^n. More precisely, the sets V_k are polyhedra, ∪(k=0 to K) V_k = R^n, and int V_i ∩ int V_j = ∅ for i ≠ j, i.e., V_i and V_j intersect at most along a boundary. Suppose that P_1,...,P_m are polyhedra such that ∪(i=1 to m) P_i = R^n, and int P_i ∩ int P_j = ∅ for i ≠ j. Can this polyhedral decomposition of R^n be described as the Voronoi regions generated by an appropriate set of points?

The sets \( V_k \) defined as the set of points in \( \mathbb{R}^n \) closest to \( x_k \) compared to all other points \( x_i \) form a Voronoi decomposition of \( \mathbb{R}^n \). This decomposition is generated by the appropriate set of points \( \{x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_K\} \), where each \( V_k \) corresponds to the Voronoi cell around \( x_k \). Therefore, the polyhedral decomposition described by the \( V_k \) sets is indeed the Voronoi decomposition generated by these points.

**Answer:** Yes, the polyhedral decomposition described by the sets \( V_k \) is the Voronoi decomposition generated by the appropriate set of points \( \{x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_K\} \).

\boxed{V_k \text{ are the Voronoi cells generated by } \{x_0, x_1, \ldots, x_K\}}
